yeah that could be where netherite  scrap came from. lots of players scraping there armour

@Macaroonuget I have thought about leather and diamond scraps, but I'm thinking in baby steps. The game already lets you melt down iron and gold equipment, so a change like this wouldn't be that outrageous. If it were to be implemented, it might be easier to convince mojang to follow up with leather.

That said, I don't know how I feel about the idea of diamond "scraps." For the most part, the idea behind this suggestion is to cannibalize mob drops. Leather scraps would fit right into that, but mobs seldom spawn with diamond, so you'd only be able to scrap things you crafted yourself or got from other players. I suppose chainmail would just give you iron scraps, but less than platemail.

Likewise, netherite, wood, and stone wouldn't really make much sense to give you scraps either. Ultimately I suppose it would depend on the devs though.
This would be excellent :)

Would have done an edit but there is a character limit.  I don't like that no one has actually challenged my argument by doing a quick Google search I found out that the largest demographic is that of 15-21 year old’s, which comprise a vast 43% of the player base. So just saying that Minecraft is a kids game and ignoring the idea when most of the players are older is just dismissive and how many under the age of 10 know how to even craft or the more advanced game play mechanics.

I think the idea of homebrewing in minecraft makes perfect sense and would be really cool. 

The mechanics already exist in game; simply putting the ingredients into a brewing stand could be enough.

Alternatively, or additionally perhaps, I like the idea of introducing a new bock or two: glass demi-johns (carboy) and kegs, for example. These could be placeable blocks (which would look great for decorative buildings) but their function could be to take the fermented product (from the brewing stand above) and then age the product. When the product is ready, players could then use bottles on the block to get a refill,  or even copper horns when they are released (viking drinking competitions, anyone?). 

The great thing about home-brewing is that it is relatively simple in terms of ingredients and a lot of the ingredients already exist in game, water, honey, sugar, apples, sweet berries, wheat... 

The secret ingredient is yeast but in medieval times, before we knew how to manafacture it they used natually occuring yeast from not only the ingredients but also from the environment so I don't think it would be necessary to include.

Apart from age, the only other argument I can think of is that (if I am correct) Mojang have rejected anything to do with real world religion and acohol is against some religions, as well as it being illegal in some countries. Mojang try to make their game available worldwide for every country and this is why religion and religious beliefs are left alone. Adding alcohol to the game could alienate some of these cultures/countries.

This all said though, I really like the idea of drink brewing as opposed to just potion brewing. I'm sure there is a way they can implement it without offending anyone.

A suggestion I saw a while ago (won't take credit here) was to have a barrel like item that can store wheat, berries or honey in. After 15 in game days, what's inside will ferment into the appropriate drink.

In regards to effects. Drinking 2 within 2 minutes or so could give the nausea effect, just like the nether portal, but in a white or something instead of purple.

I hope this gets more momentum and Mojang actually consider it.

This is more of an automatic fish farming, this should only bait fish if this thing is going to be cheap, but if you want it to bait other items then this thing must be really expensive because if not then anyone can just AFK farm stuff.
It should be hard to make too so its not too op
This sounds nice. My idea for this to make sure it's not too OP is that it can only hold 5 fish, and can only have fish.
Cool, then you wouldn’t have to stand by a lake all day waiting to catch a fish. 😀

A way to balance out the idea is the crafted "cage" would only have say 15 attempts, when you collected from it after the 15 uses it would break, forcing you to craft a new one. Also if you scale its automatic attempts to 1 every 5 minutes, it'll be less productive than AFK fishing but makes gameplay more enjoyable. Instead of AFK you can build or work your base while the trap does a tedious job. Modifying the loot table for the trap could give a higher chance for fish, then junk with than a smaller chance for treasure as well to increase balance. However, all a trap does is reduce people doing AFK fishing to grind for resources. Upgraded fish traps could have longer durability (attempts) perhaps slightly faster rates, but a trap should always be slower than a player could fish on their own.

I'm aware that posts like this get deleted but there needs to be some numbers for the stacks.
Great idea! but maybe the amounts are too much, it might be better with half of what you said.

I think it would be perfect to stack any potion in stacks of four. Players can still carry lots of potions, but they’ll have reason to use potions other than just buffs in fights because they don’t take valuable slots (where ender pearls, blocks, and golden apples need space).

What about just stacking 3 potions...
The brewing stand makes 3 so it would make sense, where the number comes from

You make 3 potins then you stack them (but not in the stand) and they must be exactly the same obviously.
This would be a good balance between not stacking VS full stacks of 16 or 64.... At least in my opinion
Stack all potions to 16 like honey bottles. This would also make it easier to make item filters for potions.

I like the idea of stacking potions but imo they should be limited to stack sized under double digits. In keeping with stack size trends, 4 or 8 would be great. The main reason I would want this is to be able to sort out fire resistance potions from the other junk in  Piglin bartering.

Stacking potions I agree. Speed, leaping, and many other potions are irrelevant or never used because beacons or conduits provide longer lasting effects. Outside of those, would you rather keep ONE potion, or SIXTY-FOUR blocks / food items? Players often forego potions because the drinks take too much space that can be better used for other items. 
So, having all potions to stack to 16 (like honey) or even 3 (brewing stand) would go a long way to make them far more useful: players can bring potions while exploring outside their beacon or conduit range and not feel the regret of losing multiple slots for 64 blocks (people would prefer to take multiple potions)
As a balance, I like the idea of a cool-down between throwing splash or lingering potions, like an enderpearl.
I heartily agree!

The pillager and vindicator captain can be summoned via commands, try

If this doesn't work, you could also replace this with Minecraft:spawn_as_illager_captain
